p: Vitamin E possesses strong antioxidant property and it can modify host immune responses [14]. The deficiency of this vitamin can lead to impairment of both cellular and humoral immune responses (Moriguchi and Muraga, 2000). Some studies revealed that administration of vitamin E may exert harmful activities in case of infectious disease. Vitamin E increased the risk of pneumonia among 50–69 years old adult smokers (Hemilä and Kaprio, 2008). Similarly, vitamin E supplementation (200 IU/day) did not significantly reduce the respiratory tract infections in elderly nursing facility residents (Meydani et al., 2004). Nevertheless, in a small pilot RCT, positive activities of vitamin E were seen in the treatment of chronic hepatitis B, where vitamin E administration markedly normalized the liver enzymes and HBV-DNA negativization (Andreone et al., 2001). Similarly, in a RCT, vitamin E supplementation increased anti-HBe seroconversion and virological response in the pediatric population (Fiorino et al., 2017).
